ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Taxes, personal finance issues such as mortgages. Most relevant to high middle class income earners.

I learned an extensive amount about Personal Finance, such as the implications, factors, and underworkings behind saving, saving for retirement, personal investing, renting vs buying a house, and many more. 

I learned so much through this course, and think it was the most practical and applicable class I have taken in my time at Yale.
I developed a foundation on applicable statistics skills towards real life personal finance scenarios.
Some knowledge of mutual funds and tax systems, a better understanding of 401Ks and retirement funds.

Stock market portfolio choice with risk aversion, labor income, and economic crisis considerations, stock/ETF/mutual fund trading, savings, earnings, Social Security, taxes, retirement savings accounts, buying vs. renting, mortgages, mortgage refinancing, debt

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: overall good. Sometimes content was too in depth, like geared toward wealth management or quantitative analysts or something, maybe could offer undergrad personal finance class that isn't so in depth.

I think the course was designed pretty much perfectly, I cannot think of anything that could be done to improve the course. Perhaps the grading curve/syllabus could have been more clear about undergraduate grading, but that is a small logistical thing.
The structure of the class allows for students to easily comprehend the material.

Extremely relevant content and assignments. The problem sets cover the topics of speculating in individual stocks, borrowing to invest, market timing, human capital and portfolio choice, saving early in life vs. late in life, income forecasting, determining likelihood of running out of money in retirement before death, Social Security benefit planning, 401k tax considerations, buy vs rent. Some additional clarity about undergraduate grading would be helpful.

Strength is that it is engaging and Professor Choi gets the students involved with the class often. One weakness is that the quizzes at the beginning of each class start exactly at the beginning of class so even if you are a minute late, you are already behind and have significantly less time. Given I was coming from a previous class, it made doing well on the quizzes (which are 30% of the final grade) relatively hard.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, very important info. good structure

I would recommend this course to any and every student at Yale. We learned so many things that will serve us very well later in life, in terms of making sound financial decisions to prepare us to be able to retire and live healthy financial lives for the rest of our lives. Professor Choi was a great professor, and made himself very available to his students.
I would recommend this course to another student because of the real life application.

I would recommend this course as it allows you to learn about practical personal finance concepts in a low stakes environment (there are no exams). However I think the course is still too academic to really change or impact how you think about your money.
